data.title: DynamicSoundEffectInstance assert on Linux
data.body:
I get an assert from within DynamicSoundEffectInstance when playing a second sound effect after a first one has finished playing.

There's a check for disposed status but it's being ignored when on OpenAL: https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Audio/SoundEffectInstancePool.cs#L108

Apparently there should be a check within `Stop()` for OpenAL and `PlatformStop()` called regardless of disposed status. Since I don't know if there's a possibility for another race condition, I didn't make it a pull request.

```
[ERROR] FATAL UNHANDLED EXCEPTION: System.ObjectDisposedException: Cannot access a disposed object.
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.DynamicSoundEffectInstance.AssertNotDisposed () <0x414e4830 + 0x00033> in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.DynamicSoundEffectInstance.Stop (Boolean immediate) <0x414e6400 + 0x00017> in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.SoundEffectInstancePool.Update () <0x413c0ca0 + 0x00085> in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.DoUpdate (Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GameTime gameTime) <0x413c0be0 + 0x00037> in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.Tick () <0x413c0540 + 0x00373> in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.SdlGamePlatform.RunLoop () <0x413c00c0 + 0x0004b> in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.Run (GameRunBehavior runBehavior) <0x41340f20 + 0x001e0> in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.Run () <0x41340ec0 + 0x00027> in <filename unknown>:0 
```

data.title: Pixel shaders don't work with Bgra5551 surfaces on DesktopGL
data.body:
I can't really write a test case for this as I don't know enough shaders but I'm quite certain I've concluded that pixel shaders don't do anything when run against Bgra5551 textures on the GL renderer. However, they do work on DX renderer.

Converting said Bgra5551 textures to 32-bit ARGB (`SurfaceFormat.Color`) makes the shader work on DesktopGL as well.

I've tested this on Linux only for DesktopGL and Windows 10 (VM) for DX without hardware acceleration with MonoGame 3.5.1 from NuGet.

data.title: Fullscreen ignoring PreferredBackBuffer values in developer branch v3.6.0.1011
data.body:
Yesterday I downloaded the last installer for developer branch (v3.6.0.1011) for Windows.

I'm doing a game using DirectX Desktop project and I was using the last stable release version (3.5.1.1679) and in this version the game work as expected, now when switching to the developer's branch installer I get the following issue:

My game is forced to run with this resolution 1024x768 regardless of the Windows screen resolution. My screen resolution is 1920x1080.

Here's the graphics initialization code

```
graphics = new GraphicsDeviceManager(this)
{
    PreferredBackBufferWidth = 1024,
    PreferredBackBufferHeight = 768,
    IsFullScreen = true,
};
```

When I run the game in full screen it's ignoring the PreferredBackBuffer values and run at 1920x1080. Here's a screenshot

![developbranch](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7717678/19619434/39a81d64-9835-11e6-9779-474f8d700764.png)

Note: The vertical lines you see don't appear while playing they appear in the screenshot only.

If I comment the statement _IsFullScreen = true,_  and run the game in a window it works well but if I switch to full screen (while playing the game) I get the same result as the previous screenshot.

This wasn't happening when using the last stable release (master branch) v3.5.1.1679

Here's a screenshot in full screen with the last stable release installer

![master](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7717678/19619443/b1e629ce-9835-11e6-9ed5-9ff804f5484c.png)

data.title: Fix for Pipeline Filter View blocking MGCB.exe output
Pipeline Filter View slows down build process

data.body:
I have a content project that takes 6 seconds to build in the regular output view.

When i switch to the filter view the same build takes a crazy **2m 17 seconds**.  Nothing else has changed... the slowdown is consistent when the filter view is enabled.

I suspect how the filter view works is very very slow.... and it happens to be blocking the MGCB.exe output stream keeping it from progressing as fast as it could.

data.title: UWP blank texture in shader
data.body:
I am porting my XNA code to Monogame 3.5.1, to a universal windows app.

Although it is a 2D app, I do not use spritebatches, I draw indexed primitives, with custom shaders.

After installing the latest VS2015 update 3, porting was easy, great job, thanks for making this so easy! 

Unfortunately only the screen was cleared in the correct color, none of my primitives were rendered. If I changed the pixel shader to output a color instead of sampling the texture, I could see the primitives. I launched the graphics debugger, and indeed the result of sampling the texture was all zero. The device state looked correct, the texture was set in slot 0. The UV coordinates were also correct.

However my shader code assigned register(t0) to the texture, but the shader assembly code used register t1... I will now try to assign textures using  the shader parameters instead of calling SetTexture on the device. Nevertheless, if I ask for register t0, I think the compiler should respect that.

I am not sure where to start to fix this issue. I will try to make a small reproducible case.

But just to make sure, are there any known issues with UWP and Monogame regarding this? I tried the latest version of the framework and tools. I had to fix a couple of issues before it ran (multisampling was set to 32, and SV_Position was not matched to POSITION). After these fixes, my app started, but still no textures.

Thanks,
Peter

data.title: Xml serialized XnaContent boolean values are handled differently from XNA in the Pipeline Tool
data.body:
The MonoGame Pipeline Tool handles booleans strictly according to the XML Schema.   Valid values are   `{true, false, 1, 0}`    Some legacy tools for for the XNA environment generate files incompatible with this standard.  Most notably in my case,  Mercury Particle Engine, which capitalizes the first letter of boolean values eg. `True`, `False`

I suggest that the Pipeline Tool should handle boolean values in a case insensitive way.

data.title: DrawString renders some fonts with black boxes?
data.body:
Steps to reproduce:
- Create new MonoGame Windows project (DirectX)
- Install any pixelly font (definitely works/breaks with [this one](http://dl.dafont.com/dl/?f=minecraftia))
- Add the following SpriteFont to your Content (use the .mgcb, of course)
  `<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
  <XnaContent xmlns:Graphics="Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Graphics">
  <Asset Type="Graphics:FontDescription">
    <FontName>Minecraftia</FontName>
    <Size>6</Size>
    <Spacing>0</Spacing>
    <UseKerning>true</UseKerning>
    <Style>Regular</Style>
    <DefaultCharacter>?</DefaultCharacter>
    <CharacterRegions>
      <CharacterRegion>
        <Start> </Start>
        <End>~</End>
      </CharacterRegion>
    </CharacterRegions>
  </Asset>
  </XnaContent>`
- Load the SpriteFont in Game1.cs (Content.Load<SpriteFont>)
- Begin the SpriteBatch with the SamplerState as PointClamp (so the font isn't blurred, still breaks without this though) and set the BlendState to anything because it breaks with any BlendState
- Draw the text in any color/position/size. I tested with this: `sb.DrawString(Font, "Text Rendering Problem", Vector2.Zero, Color.Yellow, 0f, Vector2.Zero, new Vector2(2, 2), SpriteEffects.None, 0f);`
- Note the black boxes around each letter and random black pixels below the letters themselves.

Result:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9498104/19447728/c2a2364c-9496-11e6-91b5-c96750d8a5ee.png)

data.title: Monogame app not really closing.
data.body:
Hi all. Ive been doing some game development on C++, but went on to try to use C#, since it would speed up dev time.

Anyways, my issue is the following:

I have a very basic Game.cs class (event the ones from the Monodevelop templates are enough to reproduce the issue), and everything works out fine (Starting, loading textures, handling events, etc...).

The problem starts when i try to close the window.

Be it by using the X button on the window, or by using the Exit() funcion inside, the window does not closes. The events stops being handled, but the screen remains there. I can move the window around, and no message to "Force Close" appears, but i have to click on the Stop Debugging button on Monodevelop, in order for it to go away.

The only strange thing i've noticed is that i have this on my output window:

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4778177/19373996/cac99cfc-919e-11e6-8b68-e03a35452096.png)

Seems like not all the threads oppened by monogame are closing sucessfully. I've used monogame in the past, but never got into this issue...

Here's my setup:
- Linux
- Monodevelop 5.10.1
- Monogame 3.5.1.1679
- OpenTK 1.1.0

I'm sorry for the lack of details, but please, let me know if i can do anything more to help.

data.title: No keyboard input when instancing and running MonoGame in separate threads?
data.body:
I'm not sure if this is a bug or a platform limitation, but in my project (MonoGame 3.5 Windows Desktop DirectX, Windows 10 1607), I ran a new thread that instanced MonoGame, and then ran MonoGame's .Run() method in a separate thread (so it would not block the other thread). Trying to get keyboard input from Keyboard.KeyState() in either thread brings up no keypresses, even when using the keyboard. It doesn't matter what thread it happens in, it just works as long as they're both in the same thread. I don't know if this is interesting to the developers or not.

I have to admit though, I was ripping my hair out for a good hour trying to debug this.

data.title: 3.6 Pipeline tool - Can't copy NAME of the asset anymore, it's read-only
data.body:
In XNA days the NAME of the asset in the Content Project was always copyable so you could easily add it to your solution without typo's

The 3.5 tool still let you copy, however it also copied the extension, which wasn't always desirable but it still worked.

In the latest dev branch the NAME is now read-only and you can't copy it unless you right-click and rename it, this promotes a fairly bad experience when you want to copy the name of the asset for use in your project.

Can we enable copying or at least an easy way to copy JUST the name of the asset without the extension?
P.S>
Would submit a PR myself but I'm busy doing tutorials on this stuff and getting ready for FD.

data.title: Cannot create a Texture2D with a format of Bgra4444 [DirectX, Windows Store, Windows UWP]
data.body:
I am trying to create a rendertarget with a format of Bgra4444 

This results in a backing Texture2D being created with a directX format of B4G4R4A4_UNorm

Which crashes on the line "return new SharpDX.Direct3D11.Texture2D(GraphicsDevice._d3dDevice, desc);"
in the method "internal override SharpDX.Direct3D11.Resource CreateTexture()"
in the "Texture2D.DirectX.cs" file.

I am using a version of monogame from about 1 week ago from the main dev branch.

I am building for windows UWP, and running on a machine with a GeForce 960.

I have created a graphics device with all the featureLevels from Level_9_1 to Level_10_1 inclusive.

The error is:

```
Exception thrown: 'SharpDX.SharpDXException' in SharpDX.dll
An exception of type 'SharpDX.SharpDXException' occurred in SharpDX.dll but was not handled in user code
Additional information: HRESULT: [0x80070057], Module: [General], ApiCode: [E_INVALIDARG/Invalid Arguments], Message: The parameter is incorrect.
```

Any help in getting this fixed would be very appreciated.

data.title: WinDX: ClientSizeChanged / backbuffer resizing bug fixes
data.body:
A couple of bugs were introduced by PR #4959 in regards to backbuffer resizing as follows:
- Fullscreen mode was forced to the native resolution. So it was no longer possible to set a different fullscreen resolution.
- If the window was minimised, the backbuffer was resized to 0x0.

The problem was that the `WinFormsGameWindow.OnClientSizeChanged` method was always resizing the backbuffer when the window size changed. This was regardless of whether or not fullscreen mode was enabled, or if the window was minimised.

This PR fixes this by simply skipping the backbuffer resize when fullscreen is enabled or if the window is minimised.

As a side effect of this, I've also cleaned up the `ClientSizeChanged` event. It was previously firing multiple times when switching to/from fullscreen mode. Now it only fires once (which is consistent with XNA behaviour).

P.S. I think this _might_ also fix issue #5104, but I'm not sure.

UPDATE: Confirmed to fix #5236

data.title: Set "MatrixTransform" effect-property in SpriteBatch.
data.body: Fixes issue #4387.

data.title: Improve setting BlendState in DX
data.body:
We used the BlendState and BlendFactor setters which both called SetBlendState internally. I changed this to check if either BlendState or BlendFactor is dirty and calling SetBlendState from our code so only 1 call is done. Discussed in #5176 
cc @tomspilman

data.title: Remove/Rename 'Pads' Menu in Pipeline Tool
data.body:
We should remove or rename the 'Pads' menu item from the Pipeline Tool:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/103522/19089658/ea2eb72c-8a40-11e6-9fd8-75718916ad78.png)

It is a duplication of information already available in other areas so it would be fine to remove it.

If we want to keep it we should name it "View" which is more common name for options relating to the different display panels within an application.

data.title: Improve References display in Pipeline tool
data.body:
Originally mentioned in https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/issues/4457.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/103522/19089239/175e08b2-8a3f-11e6-9eb3-6faa5c540c34.png)

The 'Collection' text here is completely unhelpful to the user.
- The 'References' property value should show a  ;  separated string of assembly names.

This makes it more similar to how VS shows lists of files/folders/macros:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/103522/19089180/dc762504-8a3e-11e6-8933-ee6952dbc53a.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/103522/19089403/c626c4e2-8a3f-11e6-8a3f-6683109e8217.png)

The display could just be the assembly names and not the full path in order to show the most useful information.  The content could be read only and require the use of the editor to make changes to it.
